pullRequest.title: DHFPROD-4864: updates to reference-entity-model project with flows
pullRequest.bodyText:
Description
Updates to reference entity model project to include loadData, flows, mappings and Zip and Address entities so mapping will not throw any error.
Sameera will use this project to spin up HC instance on an engrlab machine in a nightly basis.
It also already has hub-developer, hub-operator users and should be used to work with HC instead of admin. Demo should also be run as one of these users and not admin.
When you use this project to create a flow/mapping etc, you would have to download the project just like an HC user would and create a PR to this example project, which then will be available on successive nightlies.
Echoing whatever Rob has been suggesting so far.
Checklist:
- Note: do not change the below


Owner:


 JIRA_ID included in all the commit messages


 PR title is in the format JIRA_ID:Title


 Rebase the branch with upstream


 Squashed all commits into a single commit


 Added Tests


Reviewer:


 Reviewed Tests

commit.message: DHFPROD-4864: updates to reference-entity-model project with flows

nodes.bodyText:
We don't need nor want separate entity files. The approach for 5.3.0 is that each model file has one "primary" entity whose name is the same as info.title. Each other entity definition is considered a structured type.
Is there a particular feature that is requiring Address and Zip to be duplicated in separate files?

I don't think it's worth checking this in, because everyone will either need to modify mlHost in this file or remember to add -PmlHost= to the command line. I think for now, it's better for this file to be gitignored.
What we may want to add as a testing convenience is an e.g. "hubUseDhsDefaults=true" property so that people don't need to define the dozen or so properties below. That would make life easier in a number of ways.
I like have sample files, but let's not use abbreviations - just call it "customer1.json".

I'd like to encourage a naming practice for steps - which are processes - that are verb-oriented instead of a set of nouns. So let's do "loadCustomerJSON" and "mapCustomerJSON". I think customers should follow the same practice, so we should demonstrate that in our examples.
Even better would be to have names for the datasets other than "JSON" and "XML", as in the real world, users are likely to have e.g. "loadAbcCustomers" and "loadXyzCustomers". I think we can go with JSON and XML for now, but ideally we can have real data source names here and not just use data formats.
